title: Coffee Syrup Making Basics

items.name: Base ratio
items.details: Use 1:1 ratio (equal parts sweetener and water) for thinner syrups, or 2:1 (double sweetener to water) for thicker syrups.

items.name: Heating temperature
items.details: Heat to 190-200F (88-93C), just below boiling. Avoid boiling to prevent crystallization or flavor alteration.

items.name: Flavoring agents
items.details: Use concentrated flavoring agents (extracts, spices, fruit zest) sparingly. Strain thoroughly to remove solids.

items.name: Viscosity check
items.details: When cooled, syrup should flow easily but coat the back of a spoon without being overly runny.

items.name: Preservation
items.details: Add a splash of lemon juice (1 tsp per cup) or vodka (1 tbsp per cup) for longer shelf life.

items.name: Storage
items.details: Store in airtight glass containers in the fridge for up to 2 weeks. Let cool to room temperature before refrigerating.

items.name: Cooling process
items.details: Pour into bottle while still warm for easier handling. Leave uncovered or loosely capped to cool completely, then seal tightly.

items.name: Sweetener options
items.details: White/brown/raw sugar, honey, maple syrup, agave nectar, coconut sugar, date syrup are all viable bases.

items.name: Latte dosage
items.details: For a 36g espresso shot, start with 1-2 tbsp of syrup and adjust to taste.

notes: These baseline practices ensure consistent viscosity and flavor concentration across different syrup experiments. Add vanilla extract after removing from heat to preserve its aroma. Syrups naturally thicken as they cool.
